title: coronavirus ppe women wrong size doctors nurses uk cases
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Exclusive:&nbsp‘They tend to be designed to the size and shape of male bodies.&nbspThis is in spite of the fact that 75 per cent of&nbspNHS&nbspworkers are women,’ says British Medical Association spokesperson&nbspFemale NHS staff are putting themselves at risk due to not being able to access correctly sized protective gear&nbspduring the coronavirus emergency, doctors warned.The British Medical Association, the professional organisation for doctors, hit out at the fact personal protective equipment (PPE) tends to be designed for the “size and shape of male bodies”, despite the fact that 75 per cent of NHS workers are women.Its warning comes as the government faces mounting criticism over&nbspthe drastic shortage of PPE&nbsp— which includes essential items such as hand sanitiser, gloves, visors, aprons, and face masks&nbsp— that is&nbspplacing frontline health workers at risk of contracting the potentially deadly virus.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesDr Helen Fidler, who is deputy chair of the British Medical Association (BMA) UK Consultants Committee and a member of the BMA Council, told The Independent: “It is vital that to keep staff in clinical environments safe they have an adequate supply of PPE and that it fits correctly.“However, we are aware that in the current crisis, female doctors and other NHS staff are having issues with filtering face-piece (FFP) masks and other PPE not being available in smaller sizes as they tend to be designed to the size and shape of male bodies.”&nbspDr Fidler, who is a consultant gastroenterologist at Lewisham and Greenwich Trust, added: “This is in spite of the fact that 75 per cent of NHS workers are women. Correctly fitted PPE is essential for the protection of staff and patients, and smaller sizes need to be made available urgently.”There have been 49 confirmed deaths of NHS staff since the coronavirus crisis started, but the actual figure is expected to be substantially larger. &nbspRose Gallagher, professional lead for infection prevention and control at the Royal College of Nursing (RCN), said: “One-size-fits-all protective equipment has been a problem for frontline healthcare workers who have to wear this specialist life-saving equipment for up to 12 hours at a time.“Nurses can find it very difficult to deliver care to patients if this equipment is so uncomfortable it bruises the skin and makes them feel hot and unwell. Nurses wearing PPE need adequate breaks to rest and rehydrate, which requires them to remove and then replace the personal protective equipment.“However, many nurses are expected to work without adequate PPE or to use PPE that has not been produced to meet the required safety standards.&nbsp Nurses are now also being asked to reuse what has up to now been single-use equipment, which is completely unacceptable. Ministers must get a grip on this issue and ensure that no nurse is needlessly put in danger by a lack of masks, eye protection or gowns.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe nursing sector is&nbsppredominantly&nbspmade up of women, with nine out of 10 nurses in the UK being female.Frances O’Grady, general secretary of the Trades Union Congress (TUC), said: “Every day, frontline workers are being forced to risk their lives because they don’t have the proper protective equipment to do their jobs safely.&nbsp“With women making up nearly eight in 10&nbspof the NHS workforce, it’s a disgrace we don’t have protective uniforms in women’s sizes. Our workers deserve better.”Women struggling to access usual contraception due to Covid-19 crisisA nurse in an intensive care unit in Scotland hit out at the dearth of protective gear that fits women in a message shared by her friend on Twitter earlier in the month.The nurse said: “PPE, which myself and my colleagues are wearing for all of my 12.5 hour shift, with only 2 30 min breaks to eat, drink and pee, plus the time we are working without being paid, is designed and made to fit men.&nbsp“The majority of nurses are female. Our PPE is therefore ‘tightened to fit’ us and believe me it’s uncomfortable enough before that. This is everyday sexism and it’s an absolute horror show already. But females deserve PPE which is designed for smaller faces.”The president of&nbspthe Royal College of Anaesthetists&nbsptold The Independent&nbspdoctors should not be looking after patients amid the&nbspCovid-19&nbspcrisis if they do not have protective gear.A poll of more than 6,000 doctors across the UK by the BMA&nbspfound a substantial proportion are working without PPE, while a study by the RCN&nbspdiscovered half of nurses have felt pressure to work despite not having suitable protective gear.&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Download Damien Hirst's&nbsp‘Butterfly Heart 2020’ image&nbsphere&nbspto print out and display in your windowDamien Hirst has created a piece of art as a symbol of “solidarity and hope” to support The Independent’s Help The Hungry campaign.The Turner Prize-winning artist created the rainbow heart design filled with butterflies, one of his motifs, to pay tribute to charities and iniduals helping to feed the vulnerable during the coronavirus crisis.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHirst, who is self-isolating in his home in London, is backing our work in conjunction with the&nbspEvening Standard to support The Felix Project’s distribution of food in the capital.The Independent’s&nbspHelp The Hungry&nbspcampaign supports the work going on across the UK to ensure everyone has enough to eat during the current crisis, backed by figures such as Meghan Markle, the London mayor Sadiq Khan, Labour MP Jess Phillips and TV cook Nigella Lawson.Our campaign raises over £1.5m for the vulnerableHe said: “I am in awe of charity workers and community groups across the country who are risking their lives and health to deliver food to the most vulnerable in this time of crisis.“I want to pay tribute to them with this rainbow heart, a symbol of solidarity and hope, and support the Evening Standard and The Independent’s campaign to raise money for these vital organisations.”The Butterfly Heart&nbspimage can be printed out here.Children began displaying rainbow pictures in the windows of their homes to inspire hope after schools closed because of the pandemic.Evgeny Lebedev, shareholder of&nbspThe Independent, said: “This is a stunning artwork from one of Britain’s foremost contemporary artists. title: help the hungry food banks meals london felix project lockdown
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘We feel as though we’re making a small difference twice over’, says Oso Foundation trustee Karen Jenkel&nbspThe Felix Project, our Help The Hungry appeal partner in London, has quadrupled its supply of food to vulnerable Londoners to 42 tonnes – the equivalent of 100,000 meals a day. In the four weeks since lockdown, they have delivered 565 tonnes – a staggering 1.35 million meals.This extraordinary humanitarian effort – carried out with 22 delivery vans manned by a small army of volunteers – comes in the wake of rising food poverty and worrying new research on unemployment. &nbspThe Institute for Social and Economic Research at the University of Essex estimated at the weekend that at least 6.5 million jobs could be lost, a fifth of the national total, with the duration of the lockdown being critical as to whether job losses will be short-lived.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIt comes on top of a YouGov poll for The Food Foundation revealing that 8 million people in Britain face food insecurity and that 3&nbspmillion have already experienced hunger.As Felix scrambles to respond to the deepening distress with no government support, donations to our campaign, in conjunction with sister title the Evening Standard, are crucial to fund their fast-expanding operation.Today we can report a hugely generous donation from the Garfield Weston Foundation, who agreed to an emergency grant of £500,000 to be shared equally between The Felix Project and FareShare, London’s two biggest food surplus distributors, for their work supporting the most vulnerable families in the wake of the coronavirus.Our campaign raises over £1.5m for the vulnerablePhilippa Charles, director of the Garfield Weston Foundation, said: “Alongside significant grants to the National Emergency Trust among others, our trustees are keen to ensure that those most vulnerable and affected by this crisis receive the immediate support they need. We are delighted to support this partnership between two effective charities with which we have had long-standing relationships.”&nbspAnother donor to our appeal, which is approaching £2m, was the Oso Foundation, whose trustee Karen Jankel, said: “Doing the weekly grocery shop may have its challenges for most of us, but at least we can afford to put food on the table. The ethos behind The Felix Project appeals to us as we hate the idea of waste and so by giving them our donation, we feel as though we’re making a small difference twice over.”On Friday, Felix delivered 16 truckloads of nutritious food to community hubs in eight boroughs –​ Barnet, Enfield, Haringey, Harrow, Havering, Islington, Tower Hamlets and Waltham Forest – and a further 26 truckloads to 75 charities, schools and holiday clubs. All in all, this is the daily equivalent tonnage of three-and-a-half double-decker Routemaster buses.With more borough hubs set to come on stream in the coming days, demand for their services is set to rise yet further.The Independent is encouraging readers to help groups that are trying to feed the hungry across the country – find out how you can help here.&nbspFollow this link&nbspto donate to our campaign in London, in partnership with the Evening Standard.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: whatsapp coronavirus stickers update download covid 19 lockdown latest
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Images intended to allow people to discuss their feelings about pandemicWhatsApp has launched a set of coronavirus-themed stickers to help people talk about life under lockdown.The images were created in collaboration with the World Health Organisation, and can be posted into any chat on the platform.They feature&nbspdrawings that serve as reminders to wash hands, check in on loved ones and abide by social distancing rules. They were created to help people more accurately and easily discuss their feelings around lockdown, WhatsApp said.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe stickers are known as the Together at Home pack.We're excited to work with the World Health Organization to launch the 'Together at Home' sticker pack that will help people stay connected throughout the Covid-19 pandemic and beyond, WhatsApp said in a blog post.Stickers like these can be funny, educational and universal, breaking through language, age, and other barriers.We hope people enjoy using these stickers to check in on loved ones, particularly those that are feeling isolated, alone, and scared.WhatsApp update to bring much bigger group video callsThis pack offers creative ways to remind people to wash their hands, maintain distance, exercise, and importantly to celebrate medical heroes as well as the personal heroes in all of our lives.The pack also shows people working from home and messaging friends and family to check in on them.The sticker pack is now available inside the app, WhatsApp confirmed, with stickers localised in ten languages at launch: English, Arabic, French, German, Indonesian, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish and Turkish.Additional reporting by agenciesBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. coronavirus&nbspby the substance.“It is being used in Germany as a mist,” Mr Gohmert said. “Health care workers go through a misting tent going into the hospital and it kills the coronavirus&nbspcompletely dead not only right then.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Any time in the next 14 days that the virus touches anything that’s been sprayed it is killed.”Mr&nbspGohmert said&nbspthe government was&nbsptrying to get approval for the treatment in the US.Madlin Mekelburg, of Politifact, fact-checked Mr Gohmert’s claims in an article for the Houston Chronicle.Head of the German Hospital Association, Dr Jörn Wegner, told Ms&nbspMekelburg&nbspthat the congressman’s claims are&nbspincorrect.“What your congressman said is absolute nonsense,” Dr&nbspWegner said. “There are no such tents and there’s no powder or magical cure.”Coronavirus: Republican refuses to self-isolate, gives Capitol tourHe added that “the only protection against the story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.New York City’s former mayor spent $176 million in March aloneMichael Bloomberg spent more than $1 billion (£813m) during 104&nbspdays of his presidential campaign, it has been revealed.A Federal Election Commission filing from Monday, showed&nbspthat the former mayor&nbspspent over $1 billion in less than four months.Mr Bloomberg had a staff of more than 2,400 to help him in his presidential bid, according to ABC.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAnother&nbspbillionaire, Tom&nbspSteyer, worth approximately $1.6 billion (£1.3bn), also&nbspran&nbspfor the Democratic nomination, but only&nbspspent $340 million (£276.6m) on his campaign.The former mayor of New York City&nbspbegan his campaign to be the 2020&nbspDemocratic nominee for president, in November,&nbspbut dropped out in March.Bloomberg plans to donate $40 million to battle spread of coronavirusMr Bloomberg decided not to&nbspcompete in the states of Iowa and New Hampshire and officially started competing for the nomination on Super Tuesday, where 14 states had primaries and American Samoa held their caucus.He only won 55 delegates on the day, but did win the American Samoa Caucus.The filing shows that he spent $176 million (£143m) in March alone, despite dropping out of the race on 4 March, the day after Super Tuesday.Trump taunts Michael Bloomberg with bizarrely edited Spaceballs clipMr Bloomberg caused&nbspoutrage among his staff last month, after he broke his promise to keep his campaign team&nbspemployed until the November election.Instead of keeping his staff on to campaign for the chosen Democratic nominee, Mr Bloomberg transferred $18 million (£14.6m) to the Democratic National Committee.Some campaign organisers&nbspfiled lawsuits against the former mayor and the Republican party argued his donation broke campaign finance rules.Former vice president Joe Biden, who is the presumptive Democratic nominee, has yet to file his campaign&nbspfinances for March.No hype, just the title: kim jong un news health north korea successor leader
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Kim’s sister has been the only other member of his family to wield real power recently – but could North Korea’s patriarchy accept a female ruler?The 36-year-old has worked tirelessly in the nine years since his father Kim Jong-il’s death to concentrate power in his own grasp, purging would-be rivals and even close family members deemed a threat to his dominion.Chinese and South Korean intelligence services have poured cold water on suggestions, most prominently from CNN, that Kim’s life is in grave and immediate danger following heart surgery.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut they have also not denied outright that the leader has had some form of health scare, and Kim’s absence at recent events marking the 15 April anniversary of his grandfather Kim Il-sung, the founder of the nation, was considered highly unusual.Given the leadership of North Korea has passed down through male hereditary heirs since its founding as a country – and Kim Jong-un is believed to have no adult sons – here’s who is next in line if he were to ever be incapacitated.The only other member of the Kim family with an active role in the ruling Workers’ Party of Korea, 31-year-old Kim Yo-jong is Kim Jong-un’s younger sister and de facto chief of staff.She has been increasingly trusted with public tasks, accompanying him at recent key summits and last month making her first official public statement, as she was reinstated to the ruling party’s most powerful politburo committee.Kim Jong-un ‘in fragile condition’ after surgery in North Korea North Korea denies sending ‘nice note’ to TrumpNorth Korea fires cruise missiles into sea, says SeoulNorth Korea claims ‘not a single’ coronavirus case – can we trust it?North Korea ‘secretly asks for help to raise coronavirus testing’At the same time, it is clear from state media reports that Kim Yo-jong knows her place – behind her brother, rather than at his side. During a train stop in China early last year, she was given the job of extinguishing her brother’s cigarette.Some analysts said&nbspthat she has the only real characteristic that matters in the North Korean system – being of the “Paektu blood line”, a direct descendent of the Kim dynasty.But North Korea is also a rigid patriarchy, and her gender would most likely rule her out as anything more than a caretaker leader in the event of her brother’s demise.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailSimply put, said&nbspLeif-Eric Easley, associate professor of international studies at Ewha Womans University in Seoul: “The North Korean system could not continue in its current ideological and institutional form without an adult male descendant of Kim Il-sung.”Kim Jong-un&nbsphas a surviving older brother, who was passed over for consideration when Kim Jong-il decided which of his children to groom as the country’s next leader.Kim Jong-chol is said to have been more keen on music and playing guitar than politics, and is living a quiet life away from the spotlight in North Korea, according to Thae Yong-ho, North Korea’s former deputy ambassador in London who defected to the South.He was last spotted in 2011 enjoying an Eric Clapton concert in Singapore, according to South Korean broadcaster KBS. Like his brother, he also studied abroad in Switzerland.According to Kenji Fujimoto, the Japanese man who claims to have been the personal sushi chef for Kim Jong-il, the late North Korean leader&nbspdecided Kim Jong-chol was too “girlish” to lead the country. It would seem to be a long shot for him to return to the fold of public life.The private life of North Korea’s first family is notoriously shrouded in mystery, but we do know that he has been married to former singer and cheerleader Ri Sol-ju since 2009.South Korea’s intelligence services believe the couple have had three children – including a son born in 2010, a daughter born around 2013 and third child in 2017.Bizarrely, perhaps the best insight into the Kim family came from the 2013 visit of US basketball star Dennis Rodman, who described Kim Jong-un as a “good dad” to his then-young daughter Ju Ae.Created with Sketch.Kim Jong-un: Decade in pictures of North Korean leader Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Kim Jong-un rides a horse during take over.Nonetheless, US officials believe that keeping control of the country within the family is still the most likely outcome. Speaking on Fox News on Tuesday, Donald Trump’s national security adviser Robert O’Brien said of any succession: “The basic assumption would be maybe it would be someone in the family.”North Korea’s most senior officials have stayed in their jobs through unflinching loyalty to the Kim family, sometimes over multiple generations.In the event that new leadership is required, it is possible that several high-ranking Workers’ Party elders could team up to see the country through any transition.After decades of service including as Kim Jong-un’s first military chief, Choe Ryong-hae rose to be the North’s nominal head of state last year becoming the president of the Presidium of the Supreme People’s Assembly.He and Pak Pong-ju, a fellow politburo member and former state premier who oversaw the North’s push to introduce more elements of a free market to revive its economy, would be the likely figureheads of any collective leadership.In such a scenario, the former top nuclear envoy Kim Yong-chol and foreign minister Ri Son-gwon could be tasked with handling diplomatic issues including stalled denuclearisation talks with South Korea and Washington, as they played key roles in previous summits with Trump.“Kim now puts his younger sister, Kim Yo-jong in charge of many things, and she is the only sibling and trusted confidante inside his cabinet. title: how long when uk lockdown end coronavirus
story: ON Thursday, April , Dominic Raab told us that lockdown will be dragged out until mid-May, with experts saying it could easily last until June. The lockdown, which began on March , will be reviewed every three weeks by our top health officials who will review the data to see what we need to do to vanquish coronavirus.Mr Raab - the Foreign Secretary, who is standing in for Boris Johnson while hes recovering from Covid- at Chequers - has said that the UK must continue to work hard to bring coronavirus numbers down.On Thursday, April , the First Secretary of State revealed the outcomes from the lockdown review.He said this evening: The Government has decided the current measures must remain in place for at least the next three weeks.That means that the emergency measures first announced by Johnson on March  would stay in place.They will be reviewed again in May, when ministers will decide whether to lt any restrictions.It means that rules on going outside the house, a ban on seeing friends or family outside of the household, and on exercising just once a day, will likely stay in place for now.It comes after Mr Raab held an emergency Cobra meeting with the other devolved nations on Thursday, April .They considered scientic advice which concluded that the shutdown measures had helped Britain control the pandemic, but experts said it was not yet time to ease off on them.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has previously warned outdoor exercise could be bannediniduals continued to ignore social distancing measures.Englands chief medical officer, Prof Chris Whitty said he would expect the number of deaths to continue rising for at least two weeks past when the number of people in intensive care starts to flatten off, showing the peak is still some time away.Government advisers now believe April  is the likely peak date - but Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden believes the lockdown will last for the full three months.The lockdown is expected to be lted in stages amid Treasury fears that businesses wont survive past June.A joint survey on the impact of the coronavirus lockdown upon , UK residents found that  per cent are drinking more booze, and  per cent are arguing with their family or housemates more than normal.Nearly halfreported feeling more anxious or depressed as a result of coronavirus, while one in fivesaid they already cannot afford essential items or housing costs, the survey by Kings College London and Ipsos Mori found.Boris Johnson imposed the nationwide lockdown on March , with the restrictions due to go under review before April .The unprecedented step was put in place in an attempt to limit the spread of coronavirus.In a televised address, the Prime Minister announced police would have the power to fine peoplethey left their homes for non-essential reasons.People are allowed to leave their homes to shop for basic necessities, for one form of exercise a day and to travel to work - but onlynecessary and you cant work from home.Mr Johnson said during the address: You should not be meeting friends, you should not be meeting family members who dont live in your home, you should not be shopping except for essentials.If you dont follow the rules, the police have power to enforce them including with fines. We will immediately close all shops selling non-essential goods, other premises including libraries and places of worship.We will stop all gatherings of more than two people in public and stop all social events - excluding funerals.April : Boris Johnson tells his cabinet he is concerned lting restrictions too soon could result in a “second peak” and result in another costly lockdown. This comes shortly after the lowest UK death toll in April is announced at . title: endure only once lockdown lift timing right
story: IT is vital we endure this lockdown nightmare only once.It is gruelling for us all, is costing £billion a day and wrecking the economy. But it would be an even greater catastrophe to relax it early, suffer a second wave of infections and have to do it all again.Aside from the new toll of lost lives, many businesses which limp through one shutdown will not survive a second.So Dominic Raab’s decision to extend our virtual house arrest for three weeks seems fair while it remains unclear how successfully we are battling Covid-.He, and preferably a fit-again Boris Johnson, must time this exactly right. As the Foreign Secretary said, we are at a “delicate and dangerous stage”. But it is vital to review it every day.If the statistics show clearer progress in, say, another week, the Government must prioritise setting a date for partially reopening schools and some firms.We need light at the end of the tunnel.YET more depressing evidence of the inept complacency of Public Health England.“It is very unlikely anyone receiving care in a care home will become infected,” it glibly declared in February.Why  It was clear the virus posed its greatest threat to old folk. A care home was the perfect place for it to flourish.We have seen heroic NHS efforts to save lives and expand capacity, not least in the new Nightingale hospitals built with Army help. Britain showed our appreciation again last night at pm.But PHE’s record is woeful. For years it fixated on cutting our sugary treats, only to be blindsided by its first REAL crisis in decades. title: figures show lockdown is starting work
story: THE future of this country depends on decisions made by ministers in the weeks and months ahead.If they relax restrictions too soon, thousands more Brits will lose loved ones before their time.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Butlockdown goes on for too long, the creaking economy will finally croak — leaving millions destitute.Which is why now is the wrong moment for aggressive finger-pointing.Yes, Britain’s initial reaction to the outbreak was far from perfect. Public Health England was embarrassingly underprepared, and it’s quite possible that ministers or their scientic advisers were too blase.But we are where we are. And brave, wise, le-saving decisions are made by confident politicians at the very top of their game — not terried men and women looking over their shoulders and worrying how they’ll be judged at a massively expensive public inquiry.The Government’s lockdown strategy is backed by an overwhelming majority of the public. And the figures show that it’s starting to work. Let’s cut the backseat driving and let Boris and his team get on with it.THE PPE crisis unfolding in hospitals and care homes shames this nation.Britain has the raw materials to kit out staff. And when our doctors, nurses and carers are at risk, something has to give. Fast.WE couldn’t be more proud of the great British public.For four weeks, we’ve been cooped up indoors while the sunshine blazes through the window. But — with the exception of a few covidiots — we’ve resisted temptation and stuck to the rules.And our tremendous efforts weren’t in vain. If we gave up now, we’d face a second wave and another crippling lockdown which thousands of British companies simply couldn’t survive.Butwe hold tight, there really is light at the end of the tunnel.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking readers to sign the petition online at thesun georgecrossfornhs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trevor kavanagh public health england
story: WE are all pulling together following the rules, helping our neighbours, applauding the NHS – a genuinely United Kingdom.But the blame game is already in full swing.Labour’s vow to avoid playing party politics with a global emergency has bitten the dust, with Boris Johnson effectively accused of leaving voters to die.But it’s the Opposition’s job to oppose and politicians are paid to take the flak.Broadcasters and newspapers, including our Sunday Times stablemate, are piling in with suggestions Boris has been fiddling while Rome burned.They claim the PM was skiving on five-day weeks while spending weekends at Chevening, a “grace-and- favour country retreat” in Kent, instead of tackling the incoming apocalypse.As the earliest reports of the disease were reaching the West, the idle blighter was “sunning himself” on the luxury island of Mustique with pregnant fiancée Carrie Symonds.This, remember, was after the longest war of political attrition ever seen in a hostile House of Commons and an exhausting General Election where Boris scored a landslide victory.Nobody in Europe or America was raising the Covid- alarm at this time.As French President Emanuel Macron admitted last week, the entire Western world was caught on the hop. His government has “made mistakes” — and so has ours.But presidents and prime ministers have a lot on their plates. When it comes to health alarms, they rely on experts.It would take a very brave prime minister indeed to ignore the people appointed to safeguard the nation’s health when lives are at risk.And the advice from those experts — the sprawling Public Health England in particular — was that Britain faced no more than a larger-than-usual dose of winter flu.PHE was against German-style mass testing and, when caught flat-footed, rejected help from commercial laboratories in providing those tests.PHE failed to build stocks of personal protective equipment — including masks, gowns and gloves — despite a  test run showing these were a priority.PHE dragged its feet over sourcing ventilators for intensive-care patients and extra hospital beds.Frequently when running short of crucial gear, PHE resisted offers of outside help, leaving the NHS scrambling to catch up.And when it came to opening London’s ,-bed Nightingale emergency hospital, it was the Army that did the job in nine days.It was also PHE who insisted the British public would be protected by “herd immunity”.The sooner  per cent of the population had contracted the virus and become immune, the better, it said.Boris faithfully followed their lead until another expert, Prof Neil Ferguson, issued a nightmare prediction of , dead unless Britain was locked up overnight.It was Ferguson who in the Blair years forecast mass burials on the scale of the Great Plague during the “Mad Cow” scare and the foot-and-mouth outbreak.Neither Armageddon scenario came remotely close.Once this is over and the inevitable inquiry is held, Boris and his government will inevitably be in the dock.So will PHE, a fiercely territorial quango with a giant £.billion budget.Much of this goes on pay and perks for well-cushioned executives, with  staff on six-figure salaries — a nanny-state rich list.Its website boasts its job is to “protect and improve the nation’s health and wellbeing”.And yet this box-ticking bureaucracy — obsessed with sugary drinks and ersity — has failed at the first hurdle.It shares with the higher reaches of the NHS a suspicion of fleet-footed commercial rivals and deep-seated hostility to the “profit motive”.Criticism, still muted, is widespread within the medical community, including frontline doctors and consultants.Every Thursday at pm, a grateful nation stands and applauds NHS staff working around the clock to save lives at the risk of their own.The same cannot be said for the inflexible, politically correct quango that binds the hands of medical staff in the name of an outdated socialist credo on health provision: State good, private bad.Much will need to change after Covid-. And that change must start with Public Health England.MINISTERS are looking at a traffic-light system to lt lockdown. Red for Stop, green for Go, with amber in between.Overzealous cops and councils are being reined in. ­Common sense is taking over. Families can now attend funerals.We might be able to say goodbye to dying ­relatives. Parks will reopen to the ­public. Benches have been deemed safe to sit on.So how about allowing non-contact sporting activities that boost both physical and mental health Swimming pools are surely safe. So are tennis, badminton and golfplayers are sensible and wear gloves.Even gyms could reopensocial distancing is observed.Let’s start getting our lives back.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vintage rally car driven paul walker jump scene sale
story: The  Mark I RS was used in a dramatic scene in Fast and Furious  when the late actor Paul Walker jumped it over a highway.In the scene, which sees the car being chased by a tank, it flies over four lanes of traffic before landing seamlessly and driving off at speed.In reality, the motor was left a complete wreck - and was not used again in the Canary Islands-shot film.After the movies release in , the Escort was put in storage in the UK until it was located and bought by a collector.The enthusiast spent £, replacing almost every part on the car, ing it to immaculate condition.It has a stylish blue body, white stripes and gold wheels.Inside is a stripped-back, racing interior and under the bonnet is a . litre Vauxhall engine.Since the work was completed, the RS has covered around  miles - effectively making it a brand new car.And it has now been put up for sale with The Classic and Sportscar Centre of West Knapton, North Yorks.The dealers say they have experienced a huge amount of interest with more than , people viewing their online advert in a week.James Szkicer, from the centre, said: This is pretty much a brand new car and weve had about , views on the advert already which is a hell of a lot.There is a good market for Fast Fords at the moment and I would also expect this to appeal to film collectors and fans of the movies.It runs absolutely brilliantly and only has just a few miles on the clock.Anyone interested in purchasing the Escort should contact The Classic and Sportscar Centre.

title: coronavirus pandemic freedom britain orwell
story: IMAGINE a Britain where everyone dutully carries an identity card and the Government tracks the movements of all its terried citizens.It is a bleak world of curfews and crackdowns, of mass surveillance and monitoring systems - with facial recognition cameras looming over every street corner.In public spaces, loudspeakers blare out official safety messages. On each phone there is an app that reports back to the authorities on the users’ health and online activities.Nor is there any escape in the home. The very concept of privacy barely exists when the state can use sophisticated technology to keep watch on our behaviour.This vision sounds like a nightmare, but it could become all too real thanks to the coronavirus.In its fallout, Covid- may end up causing as much damage to our essential freedoms as to our health - with the new menace of Big Brother on its way.Already the current emergency has led to the first comprehensive lockdown in British history.Evenit has been necessary to slow the spread of the virus, it is nevertheless a draconian measure that would have been unthinkable only a few weeks ago.Effectively the entire public has been placed under house arrest.Normal le has been brought juddering to a halt, while the police have been given unprecedented powers to enforce the quarantine.Even sitting for too long on a park bench or taking a leisurely drive have become offences against the state.With heroic stoicism, the vast majority of people have accepted this policy, seeing it as the only realistic means to protect the NHS and lessen the transmission of coronavirus.They hope that once the worst of the crisis has passed, there will be ato the Britain that they love, where inidual rights are respected and the power of the state is limited.Above all, this is my deepest wish too - though the chances look slim.One of the reasons why I, as an Irishman, admire this country so much is because of the British tradition of liberty, reflected in Magna Carta, parliamentary democracy and the defeat of Nazi tyranny.Unfortunately, even when the current lockdown is lted, it is possible that heavy-handed control by the state will remain.Quarantine may be temporary, but authoritarianism could be permanent.This is because officialdom, shaken by the unexpected scale of the coronavirus crisis, will be determined to prevent its resurgence by any means necessary.That will involve far more than just the maintenance of social distancing and the wearing of face masks.An arsenal of other measures could be deployed in the fight.One will be the reintroduction of curfews at the first sign of any new flare up in cases.If there is such a setback, the mood of the authorities will be even more intolerant towards any breaches. Fines will be heavier, jail terms longer.The skies will be filled with the sound of helicopters and the sight of drones as police — or even the Army — embark on ruthless enforcement.Another change is likely to be the advent of biometric identity cards, backed up by a comprehensive database of the entire population.Such a system has long been the dream of bureaucrats in Whitehall, and the aftermath of the crisis provides the perfect excuse for its imposition.Its appeal is all the greater because the latest type of cards operate with biotechnology that scans eyes and fingerprints.Only last year, the European Union passed a regulation requiring all national identity card systems on the continent to comply with new biometric standards.The British state will not stop there in its new crusade.In the name of health protection, mobile phone companies could be required to share data on their clients.According to the New Statesman, British Telecom, which owns the EE network, is already “in talks with the Government about handing over phone location and usage data” for the purpose of monitoring adherence to the lockdown.Similarly, tracking apps on devices could also be made obligatory so that the Government will be able to trace the contacts of anyone infected and ensure compliance with quarantine rules.Just as some criminals on release have to wear electronic tags, anyone who has tested positive for the virus may be ordered to wear a medical wristband even when self-isolation is over.Alternatively, those who test negative could be given immunity certicates.These initiatives will be accompanied by a political drive to reinforce support for the state, as happens in wartime.In a distinctly un-British way, people will be encouraged to snitch on those who fail to abide by the rules.Challenges to ruling orthodoxy will be seen as a form of subversion.If that sounds far-fetched, consider how laws to tackle discrimination or terrorism are now used to uphold fashionable ideology, as highlighted in the outrageous recent case where Lincolnshire businessman Harry Miller was questioned by police for allegedly sending a “transphobic” tweet.In the new Britain scarred by corona, the whole relationship between the state and the public will be inverted.The Government is meant to be accountable to the people.But, burdened with ID cards, curfews and tracking apps, the people will be accountable to the Government.There is an echo here of the George Orwell’s novel , which painted a terrying picture of Britain under totalitarian rule.In Orwell’s society gripped by permanent crisis, the citizenry were monitored day and night by the state.The propaganda and all-seeing eye of Big Brother could never be avoided, “always watching and the voice enveloping you, asleep or awake, indoors or outdoors, in the bath or in bed.In the present global crisis, many look to the experience of Asia, which has had far lower Covid death rates than the West.But that is a dangerous stance. First it ignores the fundamental point that China is responsible for the spread of this disease through its cover-up, persecution and lies.The country should be in the dock, not garnered with praise.Second it glosses over the oppressive nature of many of these Asian regimes, particularly that run by the tyrannical Chinese communist party.China has eagerly embraced new technology, like tracking devices, facial recognition cameras, eye-scanning security barriers and online data gathering, precisely because they drastically enhance the power of the state machine.Indeed, the country likes to boast that it is building the “world’s largest camera surveillance network”.As an example, in Guangzhou province, the commercial hub of southern China, tablets have been recently installed on buses to promote safety.Passengers are expected to lean their foreheads close to the tablet so that their photos and temperatures can be taken.China is also establishing a sinister “social credit system”, where behaviour is monitored to assess a citizen’s trustworthiness.Those given high ratings by the state can receive rewards like employment offers, shorter waiting times in hospitals and discounts at hotels.It is a recipe for bureaucratic despotism and political infantilisation.Other Asian nations, while nothing like as cruel as China, are also using technology as a tool to corral their public.Hong Kong has introduced mandatory wristbands for those in quarantine so they can be tracked.Taiwan has a monitoring system known as “the electronic fence” where those who are meant to be in isolation will be visited by the authoritiesthey turn off their mobiles.In South Korea, the government gathers huge amounts of data from phone records, CCTV images, and credit cards to help track citizens during the Covid crisis, while in Singapore, phone users are encouraged to download the “TraceTogether” app.This keeps a record of all the other numbers that have been in close proximity to the smartphone, making it easier to trace anyone who might have been near the owner in the event of a positive Covid-test.Not all of these developments are bad, provided they are genuinely used as weapons against disease rather than vehicles for the expansion of state power.But we have seen since   how the excuse of security can be used as a cover for bullying by the authorities, with the result that international air travel is often a miserable experience.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.We should not allow the same to happen on a national scale in the wake of the pandemic.As the great author C.S.Lewis wrote: “Of all tyrannies, a tyranny exercised for the good of its victims may be the most oppressive.It would be better to live under robber barons than omnipotent moral busybodies.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un demise successors
story: The North Korean leader, , is said to be fighting for his le in the hermit kingdom after undergoing secret heart surgery earlier this month.The claims - first made by CNN - have since been denied by both South Korea and China.Howeverthey prove to be true the future of the nuclear state hangs in the balance as Kim has seemingly not declared a successor.Some fear the upheaval which would result from his death may even spark a civil war between rival units within the military.And with no obvious candidate to take over at the helm, a power struggle could take place behind the scenes which wouldnt look out of place on Game of Thrones.The front-runner is Kims ambitious sister Kim Yo-jong who is the single most important figure in the North Korean regime after her brother.The -year-old is seen as key to keeping the Kim dynasty in power.A less likely candidate is Kims elder brother Kim Jong-chul who may finally choose to step out of the shadows.He was overlooked by his dad as he was deemed not politically savvy or strong enough to stand up to its enemies.The -year-old was the third of Kim Jong-ils five children but was never seen as a likely ruler due to his soft personality and love of Eric Clapton.Another candidate is Kims current number two Choe Ryong-hae - who has become the leaders go to man in recent years.He didnt receive particular public attention until Jong Ils death but was then a key asset in securing Kim Jong-uns leadership .The Kim dynasty started with Kim Il-sun, the first leader and founder of the People’s Republic of North Korea, who died in .His leadership was passed down to his son, Kim Jong-il who the current Kim succeeded in .Loyal Yo-jong is the mastermind behind Kim’s carefully constructed public image, both at home and abroad and is said to have the full confidence of her ruthless brother.She is believed to be the youngest of seven siblings  and considered a “favoured member” of the Kim family.Last month she made her first public statement, condemning South Korea as a “frightened dog barking” after Seoul protested about the North’s recent live-fire military exercise.However, regional experts warn reports Kim has either died or is seriously ill are not a new thing.Dr Jim Hoare, Associate Fellow of the Asia-Pacic programme at Chatham House, told the Sun Online: You have take these reports with a pinch of salt as he has seemingly been dying since the day he took over.As two of the three members of the Politburo Standing Committee are very old, its third member Choe Ryong-hae is seen as the most likely candidate.Upon the sudden death of Kim strict rules and regulations in the system will likely play a role in deciding who will replace him.If the leadership is split on a candidate, there will then most likely be a formal vote by the Central Committee.A session of the Supreme Peoples Assembly also could be convened to elect a new head of state.However, those votes would likely be mere formalities as the real decision will be made behind the scenes.One big indicator on who will take over from Kim -he dies - will be who is named the chairperson of his funeral committee .If tradition is followed that person will almost certainly be the designated successor.Evenhe has a cardio vascular problem, which is a possibility, that does not necessarily mean death.This sister is of the bloodline and that is important but the problem is Kim has made no plans for a successor because you dont when you are in your s.However, she is a woman and there is a lot of chauvinism in both North and South Korea. The former diplomat - who has served in both Seoul and Beijing - addedKim was to die his other elder brother Kim Jong-chul may step forward.He said: The brother could be an optionhe is still around.Jong-chul is something of a playboy and has been reportedly been seen in the West attending rock concerts.Mr Hoare added:Whatever happens I dont think you can expect any kind of uprising as the elite have too much to lose.They knowthey are ided they will be vulnerable  - particularly from South Korea.David Maxwell, of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies think tank who has two decades of military service in Asia, warns nothing is straight forward when it comes to North Korea.“It is unknown whether Kim Jong-un has designated a successor,” he told the Military Times.We can speculate that perhaps his sister has been designated as his successor based on her recent promotion and the fact she has begun making official statements in her name beginning last month.Maxwell warned: “Units of the North Korean People’s Army are going to compete for resources and survival. This will lead to internal conflict among units and could escalate to widespread civil war.We can expect large numbers of the military to resist any and all outside foreign intervention to include from South Korea.Without a designated heir there will be “chaos, human suffering, instability,” added  retired South Korean Lt. Gen. Chun In-bum, the former head of his nation’s special operations forces.“It’s bad news for everyone, ” he said.Choe Ryong-hae, , is technically head of state in North Korea, although real power is wielded by Kim and his immediate family.He is considered Kims right-hand man and is frequently referred to as the regimes virtual number two official.  In his homeland he is  known as the man of many titles and is known as Kims political fixer whose role is to ensure everyone toe the line.Some reports have even suggested that one of his sons is married to Kims powerful sister.Kim Yong-chol, a party vice chairman and former top nuclear envoy would be an obvious choice to help lead the country’s international diplomacy efforts, including the stalled denuclearisation talks with Donald Trump.Another outsider is Pak Pong-ju a politburo member and former state premier who oversaw the North’s push to introduce more free market s to revive its economy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan charles newspaper boycott
story: The couples dynamite plan to stop dealing with The Sun, the Daily Mail, theand the Daily Mirror is said to have stunned Buckingham Palace officials.The Duke and Duchess  of Sussex told the four papers and their online outlets they are ceasing all co-operation because of distorted,  or invasive stories.On Sunday night, the couple issued a letter to editors of The Sun, the Daily Mail, Theand the Daily Mirror saying they will not offer themselves up as currency for an economy of click bait and distortion.A Palace insider told the Daily Mail: We have been left stunned.They have not taken any of our advice.People close to The Queen are said to have been angered that the couple announced their newspaper boycott just before Her Majestys th birthday today, and as the coronavirus pandemic rages.Harry phoned The Queen from Calornia at the weekend, but only spoke about the couples plan broadly and did not go into specic details, a source told The Times.Meghan and Harry have been accused of censorship as the Society of Editors slammed their boycott.Society of Editors executive director Ian Murray slammed said: By appearing to dictate which media they will work with and which they will ignore they, no doubt unintentionally, give succour to the rich and powerful everywhere to use their example as an excuse to attack the media when it suits them.He added: They may have been stung by some of the coverage they have not liked, they may disagree strongly with some elements of that coverage and can of course take action to answer any criticism they consider unfair or inaccurate through several channels.But the answer should never be to attempt to shun inidual titles and their millions of readers. reported the new treatment would apply to the four newspapers, their Sunday editions and their online mastheads.The Daily Star has not been named, though it is published by the group that owns the Mirror and the Express.Under the revised media policy, Harry and Meghans press team will not even answer calls from the papers.In the letter, the couple said: This policy is not about avoiding criticism. Its not about shutting down public conversation or censoring accurate reporting.Media have every right to report on and indeed have an opinion on The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, good or bad.Executive Director Ian Murray said: Although the Duke and Duchess say they support a free press and all it stands for there is no escaping their actions here amount to censorship and they are setting an unfortunate example.Although the couple may no longer style themselves as working royals, they continue to be high-profile public figures and indeed have made plain their intention to continue to do so.By appearing to dictate which media they will work with and which they will ignore they, no doubt unintentionally, give succour to the rich and powerful everywhere to use their example as an excuse to attack the media when it suits them.The truth is that Harry and Meghan have enjoyed and continue to enjoy a huge amount of positive coverage for themselves and their causes, much of it carried in the very titles they are now targeting.They may have been stung by some of the coverage they have not liked, they may disagree strongly with some elements of that coverage and can of course take action to answer any criticism they consider unfair or inaccurate through several channels.But the answer should never be to attempt to shun inidual titles and their millions of readers.But it cant be based on a lie.They also want to be very clear: this is not in any way a blanket policy for all media.The letter also added the couple had watched people they know - as well as complete strangers - have their lives completely pulled apart for no good reason, other than the fact that salacious gossip boosts advertising revenue.The couple have stepped back from their royal duties and are living in Calornia.This week, they were pictured holding hands in loved-up display as they delivered food to LA locals in need during the coronavirus crisis.Meghan and Harry donned face masks as they delivered free meals in West Hollywood for charity Project Angel Food around their new city.Prior to stepping down from the royal family, Meghan and Harry launched an attack on the UKs newspapers in a dedicated media section on their new website Sussexroyal.The couple, who said they will be adopting a revised media approach from the spring, criticised Britains royal correspondents and said they would no longer participate in the royal rota system which has been used by Buckingham Palace for decades.Meghan is involved in legal action against Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Mail On Sunday and MailOnline, over an article which reproduced parts of the handwritten letter sent to Thomas Markle, , in August .Harry described the media as a powerful force in an emotional speech just a day after saying he and his we would be stepping back from royal duties.The duke has had a complicated and dficult relationship with the press through the years. His dislike of the media has seemingly intensied since the birth of his son Archie Mountbatten-Windsor last year.Harry was  when his mum, Princess Diana was killed in a crash after her car, driven at speed, was chased through the streets of Paris by the paparazzi.Soon after he began dating Meghan, Harry attacked the media over its abuse and harassment of his then girlfriend, with Kensington Palace warning on his behalf: This is not a game - it is her le.As The Duke and Duchess of Sussex now settle into the next chapter of their lives and no longer receive any publicly funded support, we are writing to set a new media relations policy, specically as it pertains to your organisation.Like you, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex believe that a free press is a cornerstone to any democracy - particularly in moments of crisis.At its best, this free press shines light on dark places, telling stories that would otherwise go untold, standing up for whats right, challenging power, and holding those who abuse the system to account.It has been said that journalisms first obligation is to the truth. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex agree wholeheartedly.It is gravely concerning that an influential slice of the media, over many years, has sought to insulate themselves from taking accountability for what they say or print - even when they know it to be distorted, , or invasive beyond reason.When power is enjoyed without responsibility, the trust we all place in this much-needed industry is degraded. There is a real human cost to this way of doing business and it affects every corner of society.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have watched people they know - as well as complete strangers - have their lives completely pulled apart for no good reason, other than the fact that salacious gossip boosts advertising revenue.With that said, please note that The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not be engaging with your outlet.There will be no corroboration and zero engagement.This is also a policy being instated for their communications team, in order to protect that team from the side of the industry that readers never see. This policy is not about avoiding criticism.Its not about shutting down public conversation or censoring accurate reporting. Media have every right to report on and indeed have an opinion on The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, good or bad.But it cant be based on a lie. They also want to be very clear: this is not in any way a blanket policy for all media.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are looking forward to working with journalists and media organisations all over the world, engaging with grassroots media, regional and local media, and young, up-and-coming journalists, to spotlight issues and causes that so desperately need acknowledging.And they look forward to doing whatever they can to help further opportunities for more erse and underrepresented voices, who are needed now more than ever.What they wont do is offer themselves up as currency for an economy of clickbait and distortion. We are encouraged that this new approach will be heard and respected.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: So when does it start and end  What and when are Suhoor and Iftar Ramadan marks the month when the Quran was revealed to Prophet Muhammad by Allah .Ramadan will see Muslims around the world fasting during daylight hours for  days.All Muslims who have reached puberty are expected to fast during Ramadan, although there are some exceptions, including women who are menstruating or pregnant, and those suffering from illness.The rules mean food and drink, including water, are not allowed during daylight hours for the entire month. title: hero inspired tom hardy dunkirk role medals sale
story: Squadron Leader Kenny Hart crash-landed his Spitfire on the beaches of Dunkirk following a dogfight with the Luftwaffe in May .The -year-old fighter pilot then set fire to his kite with a flare gun and watched it burn to stop the Germans getting their hands on a Spitfire.A black and white photo shows the burnt out wreckage of his plane.The identical scene was replicated in the  Christopher Nolan movie when Hardys character Farrier was filmed landing a damaged Spitfire on the beach before using a flare gun to torch it.But unlike Hardys character who was taken prisoner, Sq Ldr Hart was able to get on a rescue ship to be taken back to Britain to fight another day.He was one of the Few who took part in the Battle of Britain, claiming ace status with five enemy kills by August .Sq Ldr Hart survived four crash landings in all but was tragically killed at the age of  when his Boston night-fighter plane was hit by anti-aircraft flak and engulfed in flames over Italy in December .Now  years on and his medals that include the Distinguished Flying Cross and the - Star with Battle of Britain clasp are being auctioned for an estimated £, tomorrow.Marcus Budgen, of London auctioneers Spink and Son, said: The awards of Squadron Leader Hart is a classic tale of true grit and sad loss.As a fearless -year-old he flew a Spitfire to cover the Dunkirk evacuation, downing a Me before being forced to land on the beach and torch his kite.His story must surely have influenced the identical scene portrayed by Tom Hardy in the Christopher Nolans recent movie Dunkirk.Sq Ldr Hart, from Mitcham, south London, developed a fascination for flying after walking by Croydon airport every day.Marooned in a tiny corridor of northern France the Brtiish Expeditionary Forceand their allies looked doomed.However, confident that his army would crush his enemies, Hitler made the decision to briefly halt the German advance, giving the British just enough breathing space to arrange an evacuation.This was later described as one of the evil dictators most critical mistakes and one of the great turning points of the war.Operation Dynamo, the evacuation of the BEF from the port town of Dunkirk, started on May  .On the first day, just , troops were saved by the beleaguered British fleet.However, an appeal for a smaller civilian craft to join the rescue mission proved a resounding success – by May , plucky Brits had contributed nearly  little ships to the effort.At the height of the daring evacuation, over , allied troops were brought back from France in a three-day period.By June , when Operation Dynamo ended, a total of , British and French soldiers had been saved from Dunkirk.Initially, Prime Minister Winston Churchill had predicted that only around , men could be brought home.He applied to join the RAF and was commissioned Pilot Officer in March  and posted to Spitfire unit No.  Squadron at Hornchurch, Kent, a year later.He first saw action in a spate of sorties to Dunkirk as the British Expeditionary Force was being pushed back by the Nazi Blitzkrieg.On May , his Spitfire developed engine trouble and, while under pressure, he performed a belly-landing at North Foreland, Kent.He was flying back over Dunkirk the following day but three days later he was forced to make a second emergency landing, this time on the French coast.Sq Ldr Hart and his fellow pilots encountered at least  enemy aircraft.His combat report states: I sighted several Me. s in formation line astern. I attacked the nearest from behind. I fired two bursts...I then saw the enemy aircraft fall out of formation and crash to the ground.I was then attacked from behind and forced down.After ing to Britain his second enemy kill came on June  when he shot down another Messerschmidt  over Abbeville, France.On July  over Dover he destroyed a Heinkel bomber which crashed in the sea with the loss of three of the crew.During the Battle of Britain Sq Ldr Hart was required to fly five sorties in a single day.He claimed a fourth kill - another Me  - on August  over Margate and then survived another crash landing at Foulness, Essex.On August  he gained ace status with a fth enemy plane destroyed followed by a sixth in November .He then joined No.  Squadron and served in the Middle East. He claimed three more kills while providing escort cover for RAF bombers ahead of the Allied advance on Tobruk in Libya.Sq Ldr Hart was awarded the DFC in February  for his great courage and skill in operational duties.Little is known of his RAF career for the following two years but he was posted to No.  Squadron in Italy in February .There he flew in another  sorties up until December when he was killed in action. title: new zealand coronavirus free strict lockdown
story: NEW Zealands Prime Minister Jacinda Arden said her country has done what few countries have been able to do by containing the spread of coronavirus.Placed under a strict lockdown in late March, when only about  people had tested positive for Covid-, Jacinda Arden has taken bold steps in containing the spread of the killer virus.New Zealands quick-thinking approach, when compared to the UKs dealing with coronavirus, is staggering.The lockdown measures introduced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson on March  came at a time when Britain had , confirmed cases of Covid-, as well as  fatalities.On the other hand, New Zealand had just  cases with no deaths when the lockdown was imposed there on March .The stay-at-home measures implemented to slow the rate of infection in the midst of the pandemic has since had an unprecedented effect on le in the UK as we know it.New Zealands stern approach to its lockdown follows Ardens claims that the country is in with a fighting chance of eliminating the disease.Only  people have died so far, and Ardern has been personally briefed on each death.Speaking at the Beehive in Wellington, Arden announced how New Zealanders will remain in total lockdown until April , with restrictions easingelimination progress is maintained.We have the opportunity to do something no other country has achieved: elimination of the virus, Ardern told reporters last week.But it will continue to need a team of five million behind it.New Zealand has so far avoided a widespread outbreak, and new cases have dwindled from a peak of about  per day in early April to just five on Tuesday, leaving the goal tantalisingly close.And experts believe New Zealand could eliminate Covid- altogether.The virus doesn’t have superpowers, said Helen Petousis-Harris, a vaccine expert at the University of Auckland.She added: New Zealand got everything right.Decisive action, with strong leadership and very clear communications to everybody.Ms Ardern on Monday announced the country would stay in lockdown for another week before slightly easing some work restrictions to help restart the economy.She also tried to temper expectations of her goal, saying elimination did not mean new cases would not arise in the future, but they would be stamped out immediately.New cases are likely when New Zealand eventually reopens its borders, but questions remain about how well prepared the health system is to implement effective contact tracing should a widespread outbreak occur.EvenNew Zealand does purge itself of the virus, the effects will linger as before the outbreak, tourism was booming.Some four million people visited each year, drawn by stunning scenery and the lure of adventure sports.The industry employed more than , people and accounted title: no coronavirus coffins bergamo church first time
story: THE cemetery in Italys coronavirus epicentre Lombardy has been emptied of virus victims coffins for the first time in  days after over a month of being packed full of caskets.Giorgio Gori, the Mayor of the city of Bergamo in northern Italy’s Lombardy region, shared a photo of the cemetery’s church completely empty as a sign of hope for the city as the countrys deaths dropped to their lowest in a week.Gori said the church has been used to store the coffins of coronavirus patients for more than  days, but it is now empty for the first time since the coronavirus crisis exploded.He said: “The news I can give you today is finally positive, in these weeks there has been a decrease in the infections and deaths .The image of the church from the cemetery that was occupied by the coffins of many of our neighbours gives us the idea that we have gone through the most dficult phase and we can keep on having hope.The mayor said the situation “has almost gone back to normality” and “four hotels are still hosting patients” who had been discharged from hospitals.He added: “We said that we could beat the virus and it seems it is happening.”Gomi said that from March  until Easter the city suffered over  deaths, but thanked citizens for staying indoors.It comes as Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte revealed the countrys lockdown plan would be shared at the end of this week.In a Facebook post he wrote Italy cannot give up their hard line of maximum caution and  the lockdown exit will be executed with serious scientic policy.Mr Conte added: I would like to be able to say, lets open everything. Right away.But such a decision would be irresponsible.It would make the contagion curve rise uncontrollably and would jeopardise all the efforts that weve made until now.The easing of measures must take place on the basis of a well-structured and articulated plan.On Monday, figures showed the number of infections had dropped for the first time since the outbreak began.And the countrys lowest death toll in a week was recorded Monday.Italy’s quarantine regulations are expected to be eased on May , with citizens possibly being allowed to do exercise outdoors.The mayor said they did not publish photos of the church filled with coffins in respect for the grieving families of the victims.According to the latest figures from the Johns Hopkins University, Italy has registered , cases of COVID- and , deaths.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk vaccine trials thursday matt hancock
story: THE first doses of Britains coronavirus vaccine will be given to human volunteers on Thursday, the Government has revealed.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said that a potential jab which has been developed by Oxford University will start being tested in just two days.Speaking at the Downing Street press briefing this evening, he said: I can announce that the vaccine from the Oxford project will be trialled in people from this Thursday, he said.In normal times, reaching this stage would take years and Im very proud of the work taken so far.At the same time, we will invest in manufacturing capability so thateither of these vaccines safely work, we can make it available for the British people as soon as humanely possible.He added:  I am certain that we will throw everything we’ve got at developing a vaccine.Last week Sarah Gilbert, a professor of vaccinology who is leading the team, said a vaccine could be available for use by the general public by the autumn.She said: “Personally, I have a high degree of confidence. And, I think, it has a very strong chance of working.”Asked when the first dose of the vaccine might be delivered to a trial volunteer, chief investigator Professor Andrew Pollard said it depended on when the last part of the testing from the manufacturing ended.It comes after figures revealed that less than half of the available coronavirus testing capacity has been used, leaving the Government facing an uphill battle to meet its , a day target.Downing Street insisted Boris Johnson - who is continuing his recovery from Covid- - had full confidence in Health Secretary Matt Hancock but the Government has come under fire over both its testing programme and the availability of vital equipment for health staff.Meanwhile, the Department of Health confirmed a total of , patients have died in hospital after testing positive for coronavirus in the UK as of pm on Monday - up by  from , the day before.The Government remains committed to the goal of carrying out , tests a day by the end of the month, but fewer than , were conducted in the  hours to am on Monday.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThat is despite there being capacity for , tests to have been carried out over the same period.The Prime Ministers official spokesman said the Government was absolutely standing by the target.We are increasing capacity, clearly we need to make sure that capacity is being used and thats what we are working on, he said.Some , coronavirus tests were carried out in England, Wales and Scotland in the  hours up to am on Monday.Asked about the gap in testing capacity and tests conducted, the PMs spokesman said: Ministers have been very clear that any spare capacity should be used to test NHS and social care staff and their families.As a result of the increased capacity which we have available, other critical care workers can now also get tests so that they can continue their vital work on the frontline.Meanwhile, a shipment of personal protective equipment- including , badly-needed surgical gowns - remains in Turkey despite the presence of an RAF plane on stand-by to bring it to the UK.The Government said, meanwhile, that , gowns had arrived from Burma - but with the NHS using , a day, the demand on resources remains intense.The PMs spokesman blamed unprecedented demand for PPE globally for some of the dficulties faced by the UK and other countries.There are challenges in the supply of PPE, there have been problems in ensuring that PPE gets to the right place at the right time, he acknowledged.Its the job of Government to get PPE to staff in NHS and care sectors and we are working hard to do so.With fears that staff in hospitals and care homes are risking their lives, the TUC called for an independent inquiry into the Governments handling of the issue to be mounted before the end of the year.TUC general secretary Frances OGrady said: This is a grotesque failure of planning and preparedness.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Baron Stephen Greenhalgh, a longtime ally of the Prime Minister who served as his deputy mayor for Policing, will take his seat today. MPs will be urged to stay away from the chamberat all possible - with most taking part through online video conferencing.
